Andy,

I know this tread is closed, but I want to point out that it is disingenuous of you to point to the NAS as validation of Mann's paper, and not to also point to Wegman's (sp?) paper done at the same time on request of the same Senate committee. Wegman agreed totally with M&M's criticism of Mann's paper on the statistics being fatally flawed.

Also in the oral hearings, the NAS rep said he had no problem with anything in Wegman's study, and also stated he didn't like Mann's statistics. I have a suspicion you already know this, thus not telling the whole truth?

At best Mann gets a wrong method, possibly right answer (IMO). I don't think Mann was fraudulent, I think he made an honest stat mistake and his ego will never allow him to admit it.

Craig has opened some real issues with his smart blog post. The futurist William Gibson ("Neuromancer," "Burning Chrome," "Pattern Recognition") thinks book publishing will become a boutique industry as the online library grows, and many others have argued this point of view as well. I think the portability and cheap cost of books will keep them around, but new technologies drop fast in price, and ebook readers will become better (lighter weight, longer battery life, higher resolution for easier-to-read, tougher and more durable, color instead of black and white, able to handle a variety of formats) and cheaper pretty quickly. As powerful, colorful and highly useful devices like the iPad (as its current weaknesses are corrected) are adopted, it will become possible to put some truly spectacular works of both fiction and nonfiction on them.

I think that in the end, content really is king, but design is part of the content. My own background is in programming, writing, anthropology and design. We all know that most books don't require much in the way of design, as Craig argues: a column of text with ragged or justified right margins will take care of everything but illustrated works and poetry. In the case of poetry, add more careful use of line length, but essentially the "page" stays the same. With readers the size of the iPad, and a little bigger, it will be possible to bring to these viewers fully illustrated, illuminated works.

See my book, above, if you wonder what I mean. Are others out there actually engaged in producing works to challenge the current market's thinking? If so, where are your works, so we can all see what you're up to?

I love all free, open and useful online products and I have as much invested in the Google cloud as the next American, but to hear half of these posts, it almost sounds like propaganda out of China.

I grew up in communist Romania and the revolution happened when I was 7. I can tell you, as a kid, you learn very early how to avoid mentioning your parents are listening to Radio Free Europe, that you should never say the name Reagan because that means you know more about America than you should, that any of these could take your whole family away to prisons that are more horrific than the worst around the world. You live with these and learn these things at the same time when you learn you like ice cream.

Don't put Mr. Brin down for that. Respect him for that. If you fail to do that, remember his company is making $20+ billion worldwide and if he wants to he can shape up his company's view because all his stakeholders bought stocks knowing that his and Larry's views come with it and make it the stock that it is. You want normal tech stock, buy Yahoo and MS, see how that works for you.

That said, this decision of not censoring their content anymore and leaving it up to China to block or censor it, is the best. The propaganda machine has already turned Google's actions into a west vs east culture war in China, and letting China block services as opposed to Google pulling out is the best business decision. Google will loose the least good faith credit with Chinese users by opening their services and will win ten fold with its western users. Win-win from a business side.

Others have said this and I echo it, if China wants to be global player, it should play by global rules. Can't have censorship and then then profit globally from the same "western values" it denounces at home. Maybe this will also restart the discussion about the Chinese currency and the rest of government involvement in market competition, piracy etc.
Bravo Sergey and  Google! Tell it!

I'm glad to read of this move but they should never  agreed to China's original demands for blocking access to certain sites and banning the use of key words that would lead users inside that country to content the government considers detrimental to the state. China is in a difficult position here. On the one hand, they want to be perceived as open and progressive. On the other, the concept of open speech leads to the expectation of transparency among ordinary citizens. And that's a reality they are not prepared to deal with yet.
Commenters here are showing a lack of intelligence.  33% of 600 million is 200 million. Probably as many Internet users as in all of America.  Yeah, Google was really "failing" there. Pffff.

Google has done the right thing. Bravo for Google! But the battle for Internet freedom is far from over. No doubt the real reason China wants to take a leadership position in the development and deployment of IPv6 technology is precisely because they want to put their spy and censorship tools into the new infrastructure.

Anonymous from San Mateo conveniently forgets the cyberattacks that precipitated this move on Google's part.  Google had made no motion in the direction of exiting China prior to being attacked.  Its original January memos begin with a description of the cyberattacks, including theft of intellectual property, and the most recent memo from them begins with a paragraph citing the cyberattacks as the precipitating event.  The elephant in the room is this: no one wants to publicly blame the cyberattacks on the Chinese government, but at the same time there is no reasonable explanation for why anyone else would want to hack the email accounts of a group of Chinese dissidents.  In writing "you still want the China generated ad-moolah but don't wanna abide by their laws", anonymous would have us believe either (1) that being subjected to government-sponsored cyberattacks -- as Google clearly feels it has been -- is part of the "laws" of China, or else (2) that the cyberattacks are an immaterial detail that should be swept under the carpet.  They are neither of those things -- they are a flagrantly illegal activity even under Chinese law, and they obviously precipitated the chain of events that has led to Google's closure of google.cn.

It seems many people do not believe that experience at 6 year old cannot affect a person's view of the world. I remember very clearly that all the students at my elementary school were required to stand silence in the rain for Mao's death. I was 6 at that time. I also remember that my father picked a brochure from the field and showed it to me at home. I was so scared that I insisted that I submit it to my elementary teacher. The brochure was brought from Taiwan to my hometown (Hebei provience, over a thousand miles away from Taiwan) by an air balloon. The brochure talks about the happy life in Taiwan with color photos. I was 6 or 7 years old at that time.

My 3 1/2 year-old son and I have been having this conversation about the binky. After many weeks of asking what he'd like in exchange for giving up his binkies ("another binky!") he recently settled on "a sandbox."

Every day I ask him, "Are you ready to give up your binkies and go buy a sandbox?" Every day he thinks for a moment and says, "Not yet." Secretly, I am relieved. I HATE sand.

Secretly, I also have no leg to stand on, since I sucked my fingers until I was seven. Requisite years of dental work followed.

My older sister and I are both college graduates who moved back in with our mother after college. She's been very fortunate to have been working in her field since before she even finished school; I haven't been quite as lucky, having graduated right into the recession in 2008. Our mother doesn't charge us rent, but does expect us to do cooking, cleaning and laundry. I know that we're both lucky to have a mother who genuinely is not upset that we moved back in with her. The living situation is more like three adults living together than two daughters living with their mother.

What I find a lot of people, especially older people, don't understand, is how difficult it is to live on your own on an entry level salary while paying student loans (not to mention my own sister's expensive medicine for her psoriatic arthritis). Our parents gave us no choice in the matter: we were going to college. The only problem? They couldn't afford to pay for college for either of us. We both received generous financial aid packages from our schools, but still had to take out tens of thousands of dollars in loans. And we both worked part time jobs from high school on to college. But it can only go so far, especially when your parents are in no financial situation to help you out.

How many of you that expect your children to move out are paying for your children's education yourself? They're very lucky, because graduating with no debt is a luxury very few people my age have. I hope both you and they realize this.

I seem to have done everything in the wrong order. After graduating at 17, I went almost six years where I didn't spend more than a month at a time living at home. I attended college out-of-state and got summer jobs and internships away from home. After graduation I immediately moved into my own place (well, cohabiting and with a roommate). I was proudly independent and never asked my parents for money (other than paying most of my college tuition). I made it a year and a half that way before underemployment drained my savings and breaking up with my boyfriend meant I couldn't afford my apartment. Now I'm living at home and working part-time until I enter grad school in the fall.

I did my best to convince myself that moving home wasn't all bad, that I'd get to catch up with family, that it was temporary. In any case, financially I didn't really have a choice. But having no privacy, little control over things like food, and almost no friends my own age around is undeniably lame. I also find I get along with my mom a LOT better when we aren't living together! So I'm eagerly anticipating going to grad school and having my own place again. Here's hoping that I won't ever need to move home again after grad school!
